block.p: Albright Reports Progress In Korea Missile Talks Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said ''important progress'' had been made in talks with Kim Jong Il toward persuading North Korea to ''restrain missile development and testing, as well as missile exports,'' though any final agreement would have to await further talks.
Cole Had No Special Alert Navy officials said that at the moment of a bomb attack that killed 17 sailors 13 days ago, the destroyer Cole was at a medium-level alert routine for ships in the gulf.

Clinton Telephones Arafat President Clinton called Yasir Arafat to urge him to bring West Bank and Gaza rioting under control, but got no assurances and no response to an invitation to come to Washington to try to revive peace talks.
Thousands of Jordanians marched toward the Israeli border, demanding an end to diplomatic and economic relations with Israel and condemning American support for Israel.

Victory Claim in Ivory Coast The military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, declared himself winner of the presidential election on Sunday, dissolving the electoral commission that showed him trailing his main opponent.

Bush Pledge Alarms Europeans European diplomats, officials and analysts expressed disfavor for a promise by George W. Bush that if elected president he will negotiate removal of American troops from Balkan peacekeeping duties and leave such work to Europeans.
Yugoslavia's new president, Vojislav Kostunica, acknowledged that Yugoslav forces committed widespread killings in Kosovo last year.
Europe Trims Colombia Aid The European Union, signaling reservations over Colombia's reliance on American military support, announced a package of nonmilitary aid that fell short of expectations.

G.O.P. Averts Standoff Over Family Planning Limits Congressional Republicans agreed to remove restrictions -- on Feb. 15, 2001 -- that bar private family planning groups that get federal funds from spending any money to provide abortions or promote abortion rights in other countries. The move is both a gamble that Gov. George W. Bush will win the presidency and reverse much of what Congress just did and an effort to avoid a high-profile pre-election confrontation with President Clinton, who promised a veto if the restrictions remained.

Effort to Counter Nader Effect The Democratic Party and its allies in the labor, environmental and women's movements, concerned that Ralph Nader has become a major threat to Vice President Al Gore's ability to win the presidency, are mounting aggressive campaigns in swing states to dissuade liberal voters from supporting Mr. Nader, the Green Party candidate.

Texas Test Scores Challenged A RAND Corporation study questioned the validity of rising student test scores in Texas. Aides to Gov. George W. Bush sought to discredit the findings; the Gore campaign and its supporters seized on them to attack Governor Bush on his signature issue, education.

Doctor Declares Gore Fit Vice President Al Gore is in excellent health and has not taken a sick day in the last eight years, Mr. Gore and his doctor said in their first full interviews about Mr. Gore's health. The Bush campaign said Gov. George W. Bush would allow his doctor to be interviewed, but the governor himself has so far declined to be interviewed.

Rise in Emergency Room Use Visits to emergency rooms grew about 3 percent a year from 1997 to 1999 and rose 6 to 8 percent in the last year, despite expectations that the expansion of managed care would curtail emergency room visits.

Court Finds No Favoritism In Welfare Contracts A five-justice appellate panel of the state Supreme Court ruled that Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi overstepped his authority in March, when he rejected $104 million worth of city welfare-to-work contracts after raising what the court called unfounded allegations of corruption.

Cheap-Labor Settlement Nearly 200 men and women who were homeless when they took menial dollar-an-hour jobs in the 1990's with two Midtown business improvement districts will receive awards totaling $816,000 tonight, the result of a settlement of a suit over wages.

Terror Suspect's Plea Rejected Wadih El-Hage, described as a former aide to Osama bin Laden, asked to plead guilty to charges involving the 1998 embassy bombings in Africa, but the judge rejected the plea.

Plastic Surgeon Convicted Dr. Robert Bierenbaum, accused of killing his wife in 1985 and dropping her body into the Atlantic from a plane, was found guilty of second-degree murder by a Manhattan jury.
Turmoil at Carnegie Hall The 109-year-old landmark has been swept by a wave of resignations and firings as its executive director, Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, prepares to present a strategy for change.
Mets Close the Gap The Mets beat the Yankees, 4-2, in Game 3 of the World Series. The Yankees lead the series, 2-1.
Roger Clemens was fined $50,000 for throwing a bat near Mike Piazza.
Big Sale at Xerox Xerox, which lost money in most of its businesses this quarter, will sell pieces of most of its operations.
Details on AT&T Breakup AT&T's board met to discuss details of its plan to spin off its cable television and wireless communications units and create a stock to track its consumer long-distance unit.
U.S.-Jordan Trade Pact President Clinton and King Abdullah of Jordan signed a free trade agreement that commits both countries to safeguarding worker rights and the environment.

Unions and Temporary Labor John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., plans to lead a march in Tacoma, Wash., on a little-known company that supplies temporary blue-collar workers, a sign that labor sees such businesses as a threat to unions and their members.
Editorials: Bob Franks for the Senate; in the land of Kim Jong Il; baseball in broad daylight. Columns: Paul Krugman, Maureen Dowd.
